[r 7.24] r 7.24 Power to act by solicitor (cf SCR Part 66, rule 1; DCR Part 48, rule 1; LCR Part 37, rule 1)

leg:heading.title: Power to act by solicitor (cf SCR Part 66, rule 1; DCR Part 48, rule 1; LCR Part 37, rule 1)

p.text: Every act, matter or thing which, by or under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 or these rules or otherwise by law, is required or allowed to be done by a party may be done by his or her solicitor.
Subrule (1) does not apply where the context or subject-matter otherwise indicates or requires.

level.toc-caption: [7.24.5] Conduct of proceedings without retaining a solicitor

p.text: Legislation cited in [7.24.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 7.1, r 7.1(5), r 7.2.

heading.title: Conduct of proceedings without retaining a solicitor

p.text: The general position is that an individual litigant may conduct proceedings either by a solicitor or in person. Conversely, and apart from provisions such as those contained in UCPR r 7.1 , a corporation must employ a solicitor and cannot conduct proceedings by an officer of employee: Re Education Pty Ltd and the Companies Act 1936–1960 [1963] NSWR 1340; (1963) 80 WN (NSW) 497 ; Bay Marine Pty Ltd v Clayton Country Properties Pty Ltd (1986) 8 NSWLR 104; 11 ACLR 326 ; IAC (Finances) Pty Ltd v Murphy (1971) 1 CCR (Vic) 189; Hubbard Assn of Scientologists International v Anderson (No 2) [1972] VR 577 (person who was not a solicitor could not issue proceedings in the court on behalf of a company). The permissions granted to a corporation under r 7.1 permit it to conduct proceedings by various kinds of agents, depending upon: (i) whether the corporation is subject to the Corporations Act 2001 (Cth); (ii) the particular court in which the proceedings are being conducted; and (iii) the nature of the proceedings. Subject to compliance with r 7.2 , a Corporations Act corporation may conduct proceedings in the Supreme Court or the District Court by an authorised director. In the Local Court, any corporation may conduct proceedings by any authorised officer or employee and, in relation to certain types of proceedings, by licenced commercial or real estate agents: see UCPR r 7.1(5) .

A solicitor should obtain a written authority before acting for a client in litigious proceedings: Allen v Bone (1841) Beav 493; 49 ER 429; Halsbury's Laws of England, 4th ed, Vol 44, at [85]; 4th ed reissue, Vol 44, at [101] and GJ Graham-Greene and FT Horne, Cordery's Law Relating to Solicitors, 7th ed, Butterworths, Sydney, 1981, p 50 and 9th ed at E 409; GE Dal Pont, Lawyers' Professional Responsibility in Australia and New Zealand, 2nd ed, LBC Information Services, Pyrmont, 2001. This general proposition is subject to the qualifications that:

a plaintiff may ratify proceedings commenced without authority: Omega Estates Pty Ltd v Ganke [1963] NSWR 1416; (1962) 80 WN (NSW) 1218 ; but only if the plaintiff had the capacity to act when the proceedings were commenced: Presentaciones Musicales SA v Secunda [1994] Ch 271; [1994] 2 All ER 737 ; and

a plaintiff may authorise proceedings conducted on behalf of a co-plaintiff they have indemnified (or offered to indemnify) for the costs of the proceedings: Wallace v Project Interiors Pty Ltd [1965] NSWR 1069 .

A solicitor who acts in proceedings without a retainer, or whose retainer is invalid, is liable to be ordered to pay the other party's costs in the proceedings: Simmonds v Liberal Opinion Ltd [1911] 1 KB 966 ; Omega Estates Pty Ltd v Ganke , above; Harry S Bagg's Liquidation Warehouse Pty Ltd v Whittaker (1982) 44 NSWLR 421 at 430 ; Hillig v Darkinjung Pty Ltd [2008] NSWCA 147; BC200804778 at [47]–[58] (validity of solicitor's retainer an issue in the proceedings — no costs order against solicitor).

level.toc-caption: [7.24.15] Retainer of legal practitioner — onus of proving authority

heading.title: Retainer of legal practitioner — onus of proving authority

p.text: The party impugning a legal practitioner’s authority bears the onus of proof: Hawksford v Hawksford (2005) 191 FLR 173; [2005] NSWSC 463; BC200503085 at [33]–[55] ; Wood v Inglis (2008) 68 ACSR 420; [2008] NSWSC 1147; BC200809822 at [20] ; Nicholas v Lee [2008] NSWSC 1243; BC200810319 at [17] ; Multitecfbm (Asia Pacific) Pty Ltd v Han (2008) 69 ACSR 106; [2008] NSWSC 1339; BC200811017 at [28] (general manager appointed solicitors to run litigation while disqualified from managing company — retainer subsequently approved by shareholder resolution); Halliday v Sacs Group Pty Ltd (HCA, Dawson J, 23 December 1992, unreported); Halliday v High Performance Personnel Pty Ltd (in liq) (1993) 113 ALR 637 at 639; [1993] HCA 13; BC9303570 per Mason CJ; Adams v London Improved Motor Coach Builders Ltd [1921] 1 KB 495 at 500 per Bankes LJ and at 502 per Atkin LJ; [1920] All ER Rep 340 . These decisions stand in contrast to other authorities suggesting that a solicitor bears the onus of establishing the authority to appear in the proceedings: Knox Street Apartments v Flexman [2002] NSWSC 102; BC200201888 ; Harry S Bagg's Liquidation Warehouse Pty Ltd v Whittaker (1982) 44 NSWLR 421 at 430; BC8200008 ; AW & LM Forrest Pty Ltd v Beamish (1998) 146 FLR 450; BC9804350 . The true position is that the legal onus of proof always remains with the party challenging the legal practitioner’s retainer but, depending on the quality of the moving party’s evidence, an evidential onus may move to the legal practitioner in relation to particular factual issues: Hawksford v Hawksford (2005) 191 FLR 173; [2005] NSWSC 463; BC200503085 at [55] .

It is not appropriate to permit the same party to have dual legal representation in the same proceedings. If a party has different interests in relation to parts of the subject matter of the proceedings, for example as a result of partial insurance, the appropriate course may be to join the insurer as a separate party to the proceedings: Carter v Marine Helicopters Ltd (1995) 9 ANZ Ins Cas ¶61–299; Elphick v Westfield Shopping Centre Management Company Pty Ltd [2011] NSWCA 356; BC201109092 at [3]–[11] per Young JA.

A legal practitioner who acts for a party in the proceedings has ostensible authority to settle or compromise litigation even in the absence of actual client authority: see [50,765.15]; Waugh v H P Clifford & Sons Ltd [1982] Ch 374; [1982] ANZ ConvR 472; [1982] 1 All ER 1095; [1982] 2 WLR 679 ; Donellan v Watson (1990) 21 NSWLR 335; [1991] ANZ ConvR 292; (1990) Aust Torts Reports 81-066 per Handley JA at 342; Clayton Jacobson & Lee McMillan v Ballina Shire Council [2006] NSWLEC 114; BC200601595 at [71] and [72]; Presrod Pty Ltd v Wollongong City Council [2010] NSWLEC 192; BC201007426 at [70]–[79] ; Travel Air International Pty Ltd v Raymond Bastion [2012] NSWSC 28; BC201203546 (solicitor with hearing defect claimed not to hear or understand compromise of proceedings; magistrate correct to decide that the solicitor had ostensible authority to compromise the proceedings). As to setting aside aconsent judgment or order where a legal representative acted without actual authority see [36.15.5].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.25] r 7.25 Adverse parties (cf SCR Part 66, rule 2; DCR Part 48, rule 2; LCR Part 37, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Adverse parties (cf SCR Part 66, rule 2; DCR Part 48, rule 2; LCR Part 37, rule 2)

p.text: If a solicitor or a partner of the solicitor is a party to any proceedings, or acts as solicitor for a party to any proceedings, that solicitor may not act for any other party in the proceedings, not in the same interest, except by leave of the court.

level.toc-caption: [7.25.5] Solicitors for more than one party

heading.title: Solicitors for more than one party

p.text: Plaintiffs must always be represented by the same solicitor: Herbert v Badgery (1893) 14 LR (NSW) Eq 321 ; Lewis v Daily Telegraph Ltd (No 2) [1964] 2 QB 601; [1964] 1 All ER 705 . Conversely, a solicitor cannot act (without leave) for a party to the proceedings where either the solicitor or any of their partners, acts for another party who does not have the same interest: see R v O’Halloran; Ex parte Hamer [1913] VLR 116; (1913) 19 ALR 104 .

If there are defendants who have the same interest in the proceedings, a solicitor may act for multiple defendants in the same interest without leave: Hamberger v Garrett (1909) 26 WN (NSW) 186. If defendants have different interests they must be separately represented, unless the court grants leave. In this respect the present rule reflects the position under the general law that, except in special cases, the same counsel and solicitors should not appear for two parties whose interests conflict: Nangus Pty Ltd v Charles Donovan Pty Ltd (in liq) [1989] VR 184; (1988) V ConvR 54-319 .

In will construction cases there is a practice to grant leave for a solicitor to appear for defendants in different interests unless there is likely to be an evidentiary dispute: Perpetual Trustee Co Ltd v Hardie (1904) 21 WN (NSW) 41; Re Aldous (1937) 54 WN (NSW) 51 . However, even in such cases separate counsel should be briefed to present the various arguments. Only one set of costs will usually be allowed such defendants. The same party should not be separately represented in relation to different issues or interests in the proceedings: see [7.24.20].

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.26] r 7.26 Change of solicitor or agent (cf SCR Part 66, rules 3 and 4; DCR Part 48, rule 4; LCR Part 37, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Change of solicitor or agent (cf SCR Part 66, rules 3 and 4; DCR Part 48, rule 4; LCR Part 37, rule 4)

p.text: A party for whom there is a solicitor on the record in any proceedings may change solicitors.
[subr (1) am Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[9], effective 6 March 2009]
The new solicitor on the record must hold an unrestricted practising certificate.
[subr (1A) insrt Amendment 24 of 2009 r 2 and Sch 1[10], effective 6 March 2009]
A solicitor who has another solicitor acting as his or her agent in relation to a party may change agents.
A party who changes solicitors, or whose solicitor changes agents, must file notice of the change.
A copy of the notice of change, as filed, must be served on all other active parties and, if practicable, on the former solicitor or agent.
The approved form for notice of change of solicitor or appointment of solicitor is Form 77 .
Legislation cited in [7.26.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 4.6, r 7.27, 7.29, r 7.30.

Where there are two plaintiffs, both must act in concert to effect a change of solicitor: Davy v Witt (1902) 28 VLR 24 . A notice of change of solicitor only takes effect after it has been filed and served: see r 7.30 . Accordingly, service on a solicitor who is still on the record, but who is no longer retained, is good service: Turpin v Semper (1898) 15 WN (NSW) 117. Arguably, subject to a notice of change of address for service having been given under r 4.6 , this is so even in relation to service of documents in relation to any subsequent appeal, notwithstanding the decisions in Lady de La Pole v Dick (1885) 29 Ch D 351 ; Bagley v Maple & Co (1911) 27 TLR 284.
Failure to formally record a change of solicitor is a mere irregularity which will not be fatal to the right to recover the new solicitor's costs: Mason v Grigg [1909] 2 KB 341 .

Where parties wish to remove their solicitor and act for themselves, r 7.27 or r 7.29 apply rather than the present rule. Where there are two plaintiffs, both must act in concert to effect a change of solicitor: Davy v Witt (1902) 28 VLR 24 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.27] r 7.27 Removal of solicitor (cf SCR Part 66, rule 6; DCR Part 48, rule 4; LCR Part 37, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Removal of solicitor (cf SCR Part 66, rule 6; DCR Part 48, rule 4; LCR Part 37, rule 4)

p.text: A party that terminates the authority of a solicitor to act on the party’s behalf must file notice of the termination.
A copy of the notice of termination, as filed, must be served on all other active parties and, if practicable, on the former solicitor.
Filing and service of the notice of termination on the other parties may be effected by the former solicitor.
This rule does not apply to a change of solicitor referred to in rule 7.26 .
The approved form for notice of removal of solicitor is Form 78 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.28] r 7.28 Appointment of solicitor by previously unrepresented party (cf SCR Part 66, rule 5; DCR Part 48, rule 3; LCR Part 37, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Appointment of solicitor by previously unrepresented party (cf SCR Part 66, rule 5; DCR Part 48, rule 3; LCR Part 37, rule 3)

p.text: A party that acts for himself or herself in any proceedings may afterwards appoint a solicitor to act in the proceedings on the party’s behalf.
A party that appoints a solicitor as referred to in subrule (1) must file and serve notice of the appointment.
The approved form for notice of change of solicitor or appointment of solicitor is Form 77 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.29] r 7.29 Withdrawal of solicitor (cf SCR Part 66, rule 7; DCR Part 48, rule 4; LCR Part 37, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Withdrawal of solicitor (cf SCR Part 66, rule 7; DCR Part 48, rule 4; LCR Part 37, rule 4)

p.text: A solicitor who ceases to act for a party in any proceedings may file notice of the change and serve the notice on the parties.
Except by leave of the court, a solicitor may not file or serve notice of the change unless he or she has filed and served on the client a notice of intention to file and serve the notice of change:
in the case of proceedings for which a date for trial has been fixed, at least 28 days before doing so, or
in any other case, at least 7 days before doing so.
[subrule (2) am Amendment 26 of 2009 Sch 1[3], effective 8 May 2009]

Unless notice of the change is filed with the leave of the court, a solicitor filing such a notice must include in the notice a statement as to the date on which service of the notice of intention required by subrule (2) was effected.

A solicitor may serve a notice of change or notice of intention under this rule on the former client by posting it to the former client at the residential or business address of the former client last known to the solicitor.
The approved form for notice of intention to file a notice of ceasing to act is Form 79 . Form 80 is the approved form for notice of ceasing to act.

level.toc-caption: [7.29.5] When a solicitor ceases to act

heading.title: When a solicitor ceases to act

p.text: The notice requirements of the present rule apply where a solicitor “ceases to act for a party”. The rule applies where, as a matter of fact, a solicitor ceases to act. It is not concerned with the propriety or the validity of solicitor's conduct as against the client: Plenty v Gladwin (1986) 67 ALR 26; 60 ALJR 665; BC8601460 (solicitors ceasing to act after allegations of serious unethical conduct) and Re Falgat Constructions Pty Ltd (1996) 137 ALR 37; 70 ALJR 609; [1996] 10 Leg Rep 13; BC9602402 (ceasing to act after being informed new solicitors had been retained).

A solicitor's retainer, particularly in relation to contentious business, will usually constitute an entire contract. Consequently, the solicitor must complete the work, by conducting the proceedings to completion, unless the client releases or dismisses the solicitor, or the solicitor terminates the for good cause and on reasonable notice: see generally Solicitors Rules –– Revised Professional Conduct and Practice Rules 1995 r 5. A solicitor who improperly purports to terminate a retainer that involves an entire contract will lose the right to recover any remuneration, and with it, any right to a lien over the client's documents: Riley Solicitors Manual [3125.5] and [3145.20]. Good cause for termination of the retainer includes:
the solicitor's physical incapacity through injury or disease: Forney v Bushe (1954) 104 LJo 604

client failure to provide money for costs or disbursements: Wadsworth v Marshall (1832) 2 Cr & J 665; 149 ER 279; Robins v Goldingham (1872) LR13Eq 440 ; Warmingtons v McMurray [1937] 1 All ER 562; (1937) 53 TLR 395 ; Super 1000 Pty Ltd v Pacific General Securities Ltd [2007] NSWSC 171; BC200701277 (failure to provide funds for costs)
where the client requires the solicitor to act improperly or where the proceedings cannot properly be continued: Lawrence v Potts (1834) 6 C & P 428; 172 ER 1306

where the client prevents the solicitor from properly carrying out the duties required by the retainer: Underwood Son & Piper v Lewis [1894] 2 QB 306 at 314 is required by the client to do something dishonourable, or where the solicitor is prevented by the client

It will not normally be appropriate to dispense with, or abridge, a solicitor’s obligation under UCPR r 7.29(2) to give the client notice of intention to cease to act. Notice may be dispensed with if the court is satisfied that the solicitor has good cause for immediate termination of the retainer, or is otherwise unable to comply with the notice requirement. The court may also dispense with the requirement for prior notice to the client if the evidence establishes that the has in fact been terminated and the client is aware of that fact: Plenty v Gladwin (1986) 67 ALR 26; 60 ALJR 665; BC8601460 ; Super 1000 Pty Ltd v Pacific General Securities Ltd [2007] NSWSC 171; BC200701277 at [13] (leave granted to file a notice of ceasing to act on the morning of proceedings). In an exceptional case, where the application was made after the hearing had concluded, and the solicitors had relied on the client’s failure to pay costs, the court refused leave, but without purporting to decide that the solicitors were obliged to continue to act in the proceedings: Cha v Oh (No 21) (2009) 9 DCLR (NSW) 67; [2009] NSWDC 130; BC200940253 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.30] r 7.30 Effect of change (cf SCR Part 66, rule 8; DCR Part 48, rule 5; LCR Part 37, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Effect of change (cf SCR Part 66, rule 8; DCR Part 48, rule 5; LCR Part 37, rule 5)

p.text: A change for which notice is required or permitted to be given under this Division does not take effect:
as regards the court, until the notice is filed, and
as regards any person on whom it is required or permitted to be served, until a copy of the notice, as filed, is served on that person.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 7.31] r 7.31 Actions by a solicitor corporation (cf SCR Part 66, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Actions by a solicitor corporation (cf SCR Part 66, rule 10)

p.text: Where, by or under the Civil Procedure Act 2005 or these rules or otherwise by law:
any act, matter or thing is authorised or required to be done by a solicitor for a person, and
the solicitor is a solicitor corporation, and

the act, matter or thing can, in the circumstances of the case, only be done by a natural person, the act, matter or thing may be done by a solicitor who is a director, officer or employee of the corporation.
